title: 107_s691
content: The Washoe Tribe Land Conveyance is addressed in Section 1. Congress finds that the Washoe Tribe's ancestral homeland encompassed approximately 5,000 square miles around Lake Tahoe, California and Nevada. In 1997, the Washoe people were recognized as indigenous to the Lake Tahoe Basin through meetings convened by various levels of government and private landholders. The Washoe Tribe's indigenous status in the Lake Tahoe Basin was recognized through meetings held at 2 locations to protect the region's natural resources. A multiagency agreement supports the Tribe's traditional land uses and provides access to Lake Tahoe for cultural practices. The Washoe Tribe's indigenous status in the Lake Tahoe Basin was recognized to provide access to the shore of Lake Tahoe for traditional cultural practices, including spiritual renewal and land stewardship. The Act aims to return the Tribe to Lake Tahoe and ensure opportunities for engaging in customary practices. The Act aims to ensure that the Washoe Tribe has access to engage in traditional cultural practices on the shore of Lake Tahoe for spiritual renewal, land stewardship, horticulture, subsistence gathering, and family bonds through a conveyance of land from the Secretary of Agriculture to the Secretary of the Interior in trust for the Tribe. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey approximately 24.3 acres of land to the Secretary of the Interior in trust for the Washoe Tribe, with a reserved easement for public and administrative access. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey approximately 24.3 acres of land to the Secretary of the Interior in trust for the Washoe Tribe, with a reserved easement for public and administrative access over Forest Development Road #15N67. The Tribe will also receive a reciprocal easement for vehicular access for administrative and safety purposes. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a reciprocal easement to the Washoe Tribe for vehicular access to the conveyed parcel over Forest Development Road #15N67 for administrative, safety, and accessibility purposes. The Tribe and its members must limit the use of the parcel to traditional and customary uses and stewardship. The Tribe and its members must limit the use of the conveyed parcel to traditional and customary uses, conservation, and comply with environmental requirements. No permanent residential, recreational, or commercial development is allowed on the parcel. The Tribe must limit the use of the conveyed parcel to traditional and customary uses, conservation, and comply with environmental requirements. No permanent residential, recreational, or commercial development is allowed on the parcel. Additionally, any development on the parcel must comply with environmental requirements no less protective than those of the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency. If the Secretary of the Interior finds that the Tribe has violated these conditions, the parcel may be terminated and reverted. If the Secretary of the Interior finds that the Tribe has violated the conditions for use of the parcel, they may terminate and revert the title to the parcel. The Senate passed the document on August 1, 2002, with Jeri Thomson as the Secretary.
